This summer, I worked at Posit (formerly RStudio), focusing on machine learning, software development, and more as part of the tidymodels [^tidymodels] team. I primarily worked on {filtro}, a filter-based supervised feature selection package for modeling and machine learning in R.

[^tidymodels]: {tidymodels} can be thought of as an R framework comparable to {scikit-learn} in Python.

### S3 OOP Brush-Up

Week 1-4

To be completely honest, while Xiaotian's {mtd} [^mtd] package is quite well-organized ‚Äî and I would argue that the most challenging aspect of extending it lies more in model development than in software engineering, I had little to no experience with R's S3 OOP system. So here I am, pretty much glued to the *Advanced R* and *R Packages* books and poking around the {tune} package (plus {yardstick} and a few others) through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game. 

[^mtd]: This is the package I build upon in my PhD dissertation. See Xiaotian's package at [https://github.com/xzheng42/mtd](https://github.com/xzheng42/mtd). My extended version will be available on GitHub in late December or later. ü§û

Week 5

Max, Hadley, and I met to discuss the API design for the {desirability2} package. During the discussion, Hadley demonstrated some code using S7 [^S7] and recommended incorporating it. üò± (That's the "face screaming in fear" emoji because I am both thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, but nervous about living up to expectations!)

### CRAN Horror Story to Acceptance and Dual Branches

Week 6

I had to resubmit the package after making a few reasonable but minimal errors. Following the resubmission, the reviewer emailed me asking for revisions, with no further details. Gathering my courage, I replied back for clarification, and shortly after received an apology along with the great news that {filtro} is now on CRAN. üöÄ

The S3 branch was now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lived on as the development version ‚Äî many branches ahead in features and updates. In practice, though, I was juggling multiple branches, as I got used to merging, resolving conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows, though I still find CI/CD concepts a bit abstract and challenging.

### Write, Write, and Write... 

Week 9

- Write, write, and write, (but *not* the dissertation kind!)  

Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting the other intern, Jules, as well as other developers based in Europe and across the US. The most fun, though initially intimidating, experience was the tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib [^rlib] teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the key people at Posit all at once [^tidymodelmeeting]. 

[^rlib]: Some of the most useful developer tools we used daily, such as {devtools}, {usethis}, {testthat}, and {rlang}, were all developed by the r-lib team [https://github.com/r-lib](https://github.com/r-lib).

[^tidymodelmeeting]: I also really enjoyed the weekly tidymodels meeting because it brought together people like Max, Emil, Hannah, and Simon, whose work was more relevant to mine. That said, I have to admit that sometimes I got overwhelmed by the many details involved in the *many* packages maintained by the team. Simon‚Äôs work on AI assistance through LLM integration, however, was quite intriguing.
